options.label: C

options.label: B

title: How does herd immunity work?

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of vaccines, aside from protecting individuals from getting sick?

options.label: A
options.text: To protect a whole population by getting enough people immune to a disease.

options.label: B
options.text: To cure diseases that have already infected people.

options.label: C
options.text: To reduce the severity of diseases.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of "herd immunity" in the context of vaccines?

options.label: A
options.text: It refers to the idea that a certain percentage of the population needs to be immune to a disease in order to stop its spread.

options.label: B
options.text: It refers to the idea that vaccines are only effective for a certain percentage of the population.

options.label: C
options.text: It refers to the idea that people who are vaccinated are completely immune to diseases.

options.label: D
options.text: It refers to the idea that vaccines are only necessary for people who are at high risk of getting a disease.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "herd threshold" in the context of vaccines?

options.label: A
options.text: It refers to the minimum number of people who need to be vaccinated in order to stop the spread of a disease.

options.label: B
options.text: It refers to the maximum number of people who can be vaccinated in order to stop the spread of a disease.

options.label: C
options.text: It refers to the percentage of the population that needs to be immune to a disease in order to stop its spread.

options.label: D
options.text: It refers to the number of people who are at high risk of getting a disease.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the estimated number of deaths prevented by vaccines every year?
What is the main challenge facing public health officials in terms of vaccines?

options.label: A
options.text: Making sure people understand the importance of vaccines.

options.label: B
options.text: Making enough vaccines to meet demand.

title: How short selling works

multiple-choice.question: What is short selling in the context of investing?

options.label: A
options.text: Buying a security today and selling it in the future, hoping the price will go up.

options.label: B
options.text: Selling a security today and buying it back in the future, hoping the price will go down.

options.label: C
options.text: Holding onto a security for a long period of time, hoping the price will increase.

options.label: D
options.text: Diversifying a portfolio by investing in multiple securities.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of margin in the context of short selling?

options.label: A
options.text: The amount of money an investor must contribute to their account to cover potential losses.

options.label: B
options.text: The amount of money an investor can borrow from their broker to cover potential losses.

options.label: C
options.text: The amount of money an investor must pay to their broker as a fee for short selling.

options.label: D
options.text: The amount of money an investor can earn from short selling.

multiple-choice.question: What is a short squeeze in the context of investing?

options.label: A
options.text: When a heavily shorted stock sees its price surge because investors need to cover their positions.

options.label: B
options.text: When a heavily shorted stock sees its price drop because investors need to cover their positions.

options.label: C
options.text: When a broker forces an investor to prematurely cover their short position.

options.label: D
options.text: When an investor decides to close their short position early.

multiple-choice.question: What is the risk-reward profile of short selling compared to long investing?

options.label: A
options.text: Short selling has a higher potential return and lower potential loss.

options.label: B
options.text: Short selling has a lower potential return and higher potential loss.

options.label: C
options.text: Short selling has a skewed payoff, with limited upside and unlimited downside.

options.label: D
options.text: Short selling has a symmetrical payoff, with equal potential return and loss.

multiple-choice.question: Why do many investors tend to avoid short selling?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is too complex and difficult to understand.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it requires a lot of capital and resources.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the potential return is not worth the risk.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is not a viable investment strategy.

title: Why the ancient Greeks couldn't see blue

multiple-choice.question: What is the typical order in which colors enter a language, according to researchers?

options.label: B
options.text: Black, white, red, yellow, green, blue

options.label: C
options.text: Red, blue, green, yellow, black, white

options.label: D
options.text: Green, yellow, blue, red, black, white

multiple-choice.question: Why did ancient civilizations, such as the Greeks, not mention the color blue in their writings?

options.label: B
options.text: They saw colors differently than we do.

options.label: C
options.text: Blue was not a significant color in their environment.

options.label: D
options.text: They did not have a word for blue.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of language on our perception of colors, according to neuroscience?

options.text: Language has no effect on our perception of colors.

options.label: B
options.text: Language influences our perception of colors, but only in a minor way.

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: How to process your emotions

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what happens when we fail to process our emotions?

options.label: A
options.text: We become more confident and self-assured.

options.label: B
options.text: We grow depressed about everything because we cannot be sad about something.

options.label: C
options.text: We become more energetic and motivated.

options.label: D
options.text: We develop a more optimistic outlook on life.

multiple-choice.question: Why do we often avoid processing our emotions?

options.label: B
options.text: Because it's not considered important in our society.

options.label: C
options.text: Because what we feel is so contrary to our self-image, so threatening to our society's ideas of normality, and so at odds with who we would really like to be.

options.label: D
options.text: Because we don't have the necessary tools and resources.

multiple-choice.question: What is the outcome of processing our emotions?

options.label: A
options.text: A worsening of our general mood.

options.label: B
options.text: An alleviation in our general mood.

options.label: C
options.text: No change in our general mood.

options.label: D
options.text: A temporary improvement in our general mood.

multiple-choice.question: What do we need in order to process our emotions effectively?

options.label: C
options.text: A combination of good friends, deft therapists, and ritual moments like philosophical meditation.

multiple-choice.question: Why do we often numb ourselves chemically or adopt a tone of cynicism?

options.label: A
options.text: To avoid feeling happy and content.

options.label: B
options.text: To avoid feeling sad and vulnerable.

options.label: C
options.text: To avoid feeling angry and frustrated.

options.label: D
options.text: To avoid feeling bored and uninterested.
